 is hosting their annual Women's Leadership Conference (WLC) designed for Asian-heritage women professionals, and is open to anyone.
 
Our CEO Farah Bala will be speaking on the topic of 
Unlocking Career Growth Through Self Leadership 
on Friday, April 25, 2025.
 
REGISTER HERE - WLC April 25, 2025
FARSIGHT is thrilled to partner with our friends at 
The Serica Initiative
 to create their pilot

. We love their work and mission to amplify AAPI voices and communities across the globe and it is an honor to support them in this new initiative!
 
If you are an NYC-based, woman AAPI people-leader looking to deepen your leadership and influence through mentor support, and would like to apply, 
Applications open tomorrow, April 2, 2025

It makes every episode possible!

FARSIGHT
 FRIDAY
 
started in response to the multiple pandemics that have fueled racism and division in the United States and around the world in 2020. This video podcast attempts to dissect topics, new and old, that are current to our times.
 
We hope these episodes give you an 
opportunity to check in, reflect, and process how you are experiencing these times. We learn a lot by being in conversation, and by listening to diverse perspectives. Please continue these conversations with your communities, your families, your teams, your organizations. The more we speak of these topics, the more we normalize their existence and complexity; providing the crucial antidote to erasure and division.

subject: An email was logged on records you're following
body:
An email was logged on records you're following
 
 
Hi, colleagues. Sorry for sending yet another email, but wanted to let you know that after reading 
the actual EEOC document
, it seems to me that Paradigm’s last row below can be confusing or even misleading. Regarding training, the EEOC guidelines state: 
  
Title VII also prohibits employers from limiting, segregating, or classifying employees or applicants based on race, sex, or other protected characteristics in a way that affects their status or deprives them of employment opportunities...
[28]
  
  
Unlawful limiting, segregating, or classifying workers related to DEI can arise when employers separate workers into groups based on race, sex, or another protected characteristic when administering DEI or any trainings, workplace programming, or other privileges of employment, even if the separate groups receive the same programming content or amount of employer resources.
[31]
… 
  
Employers instead should provide “training and mentoring that provides workers 
of all backgrounds
 the opportunity, skill, experience, and information necessary to perform well, and to ascend to upper-level jobs.”
[32]
  
  
So I interpret the above as separating workers in terms of who participates or is given the oppty to attend the training, not the 
content
 of the training. 
  
Just wanted to clarify that. RP 
  
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
 
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
 
Head of Client Solutions 
LCW

At the same time, 6 in 10 decision makers prefer getting emails over LinkedIn DMs or phone calls.

Cold email is a viable way to grow almost any business, from a multi-billion dollar enterprise to a local photography studio.
However, persistent misconceptions still make some business leaders shy away from it. We dispel 9 of those myths here.

   From: Rocio Alvarez Sent: Thursday, March 20, 2025 5:16 PM To: Chuck Adams Subject: Re: LCW Quotes for Programming Thank you very much, Chuck! I've had some time to go through the menu and have a few questions about pricing for each course. I'm interested in the following sessions, divided by type. Are they priced by the hour, by the session or both? It's a little of both and the number of faciltators. Let's assume we have 40 people in each session, would we need 3 or 4 sessions of each? We usually suggest that sessions be limited to 25-30 people in order to maximize interaction and engagement. We find that active participation suffers as the number of participants increases. We are flexible, though.  Facilitated learning Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion (all audiences)  Pricing is $8,000 per session.  Inclusion Skill-Building: Brave Conversations on Race + Power of Allyship Culture (all audiences) Pricing is $8,000 per session for each .  Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion Pricing is $12,000  per session + Leading with Conscious Inclusion (managers & leaders)  Pricing is $8,000 per session ELearning - We have two models for elearning; 1) a price based on org size which starts at $20k for up to 10,000 users, and 2) for smaller organizations we host the modules for $50 for each user (for 12 months). The latter would work best for you folks. Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion (all audiences) Fostering Collaboration (all audiences) Mini-workshops Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion Price is $3,600 per session Spotlight on Intersectionality Price is $3,600 per session I realize I am repeating myself with the foundations courses, but I think it's important to offer this in different ways so the message clicks for everyone, and also because I don't know that everyone will attend each kind of session. Can you tell me what the cost of those selections would be, based on a company of 160 people? We have 50-60 people who are people managers and would be in the manager & leader sessions. Thank you! On Mon, Mar 10, 2025 at 2:05 PM Chuck Adams < c.adams@lcwmail.com: mailto:c.adams@lcwmail.com> wrote: Hi, Rocio –   Attached are the information deck and  proposal with pricing we discussed. Don’t be put off by the final cost in the proposal. 😊  To build the proposal I had to assume some things around the final number of sessions and the specific manager/leader training you might be interested in. Note that any of the products in the deck can be swapped out for assumptions made in the proposal.   Either way, think of this as a menu that we can customize accordingly.   You’ll notice that I did not provide pricing on the Diversity Leadership Governance piece yet. I need to talk with the team about how best to represent that outside of the ERG/BRG Consulting Package. As I was reviewing the program I noticed that there wasn’t a clean line item for that piece alone. I will work to get you that tomorrow.   Please let me know if you want to meet and discuss anything sent here. We can schedule a follow up call for end of this week/early next week at your convenience.   Best,   Chuck   Chuck Adams (He/Him) Chief Executive Officer LCW Office: +1.773.938.4285 Mobile: +1.630.373.5068     Website:

Hi Jacquie, 
Wow, you almost broke 100 participants, that is fantastic.  Chuck thought that the session went well.  He and Hanadi enjoy working together.  I hope your colleagues felt it was time well spent.  Any feedback is always appreciated. 
  
The session evaluation data should be ready early next week.  I like to give folks a couple of days to complete the survey, and then send results to you.  To be honest, I am not sure why the transcript function was turned on.  In general, we do not provide a copy of the session transcript.   I hope you will understand.  
  
Perhaps we can touch base next week.  It would be great to know what Della had to say as well.  I will send the survey results, and then you and I can talk about the potential for additional sessions of interest for your organization.     
  
Have a great rest of the week.  It is a pleasure working with you.

I’d also replace the second quote under item #1 to make it broader and applicable to different industries. I wrote that quote for GroupM, a media planning organization. So maybe replace with: 
  
“If we make business decisions based on outdated assumptions, we risk missing opportunities and alienating potential customers. When we understand and work to meet the needs of a diverse marketplace, we’ll have stronger customer engagement and better business outcomes." 
  
I also wrote the second quote under item #2 for GroupM. So I’d edit that one to: 
“If our company wants to be the best in the marketplace, we must understand
...” 
  
I agree with Chuck’s suggestion for the example for item #3. I’d recommend using ‘employee’ (or even ‘manager’) instead of ‘worker.’   
  
Re: item #4 and Chuck’s suggestion, I might add a third line as opposed to replacing one of the answers that are already there. I would also slightly edit the language to:  
“Quotas have been illegal for some time. Often people confuse quotas with earnest attempts to include a broader pool of qualified candidates so we can have a better chance of selecting the best people for our open roles.”
 
  
Re: item #5, an example statement could be 
“I don’t know why people make such a big deal about inclusion. People just need to have thicker skin”.
 The quote intentionally brings up where you grew up because it’s meant to generate empathy and understanding from a privileged (non-underrepresented) person. 
  
Re: item #6, I like Chuck’s suggestion and would slightly edit it thusly: 
“Why should we devote time and money to inclusion? We’re a profit-seeking company.” 
  
Re: Chuck’s suggestion about a statement that ties DEI to company values, we could add a second line under item #5 (“Appeal to Fairness & Ethics”) that touches on this. For example: 
“If we want to live out our corporate values of excellence, innovation, and customer commitment, we must create an environment where every employee can contribute their best work.  When we foster an inclusive culture where everyone is engaged and able to contribute fully, we unlock the full potential of our people—our most valuable asset."
 
  
If you provide me with the PPT, I can make all these changes myself and then resend to Keri.

subject: Spring into Earth Day
body:
BrainPOP has all you need—from natural resources to pollution
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
Spring is bursting with new life, and so is our April newsletter! Get ready to plant the seeds of Earth Day knowledge with this month's lesson ideas and watch your students’ brains grow with ideas. 
 
 
 
 
 
Engage students with topics like… 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Natural Resources 
 
Introduce learners to Earth's resources— from air and minerals to renewable vs nonrenewable—and why conservation matters. 
 
Explore topic
 
 
 
 
 
 
How do visible and invisible sources of pollution affect the environment? 
 
This free investigation lets middle schoolers discover causes and effects of water, air, and light pollution. 
 
Explore Investigation
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Using teaching strategies like… 
 
“Five learning activities, shared by teachers of all subject areas, for how to easily and meaningfully integrate Earth Day activities across the curriculum.” 
 
5 Activities to Celebrate Earth Day
 
 
 
 
 
And read stories about… 
 
 
 
 
 
Why Teachers Who Grew Up on BrainPOP Choose it in Their Classrooms Today

Hey, folks -  
It was great chatting with you two this afternoon. I think you're on the right track in considering how best to support your ERG leaders and the executive sponsors who support/guide them.... especially during these times. Our program has been very well received by our clients and I'm sure would prove an effective tool to help to strengthen your ERGs. 
In the quote, you'll see the trainings, the customizations (estimate), and the handbook. Again, the handbook can be removed if you don't feel that you need to memorialize the best practices for future leaders/sponsors.  
Let me know if you have any questions about any of this and we can discuss options to ensure we can fit within your budget. 
I'll reach out next week to continue the conversation. 
Chuck

From:
 Rocio Alvarez
Sent:
 Thursday, March 20, 2025 5:16 PM
To:
 Chuck Adams
Subject:
 Re: LCW Quotes for Programming 
Thank you very much, Chuck! I've had some time to go through the menu and have a few questions about pricing for each course. 
I'm interested in the following sessions, divided by type. Are they priced by the hour, by the session or both? 
It's a little of both and the number of faciltators.
 Let's assume we have 40 people in each session, would we need 3 or 4 sessions of each? 
We usually suggest that sessions be limited to 25-30 people in order to maximize interaction and engagement. We find that active participation suffers as the number of participants increases. We are flexible, though. 
 
Facilitated learning
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion (all audiences)  
Pricing is $8,000 per session. 
 
Inclusion Skill-Building: Brave Conversations on Race + Power of Allyship Culture (all audiences) 
Pricing is $8,000 
per session for each
 
. 
 
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion 
Pricing is $12,000
 
 per session
 + Leading with Conscious Inclusion (managers & leaders)  
Pricing is $8,000 
per session
 
ELearning -
 We have two models for elearning; 1) a price based on org size which starts at $20k for up to 10,000 users, and 2) for smaller organizations we host the modules for $50 for each user (for 12 months). The latter would work best for you folks.
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion (all audiences)
Fostering Collaboration (all audiences)
Mini-workshops
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion
 Price is $3,600
 per session
Spotlight on Intersectionality 
Price is $3,600 per session
I realize I am repeating myself with the foundations courses, but I think it's important to offer this in different ways so the message clicks for everyone, and also because I don't know that everyone will attend each kind of session. 
Can you tell me what the cost of those selections would be, based on a company of 160 people? We have 50-60 people who are people managers and would be in the manager & leader sessions. 
Thank you! 
On Mon, Mar 10, 2025 at 2:05 PM Chuck Adams < 
c.adams@lcwmail.com
> wrote: 
Hi, Rocio –
 
Attached are the information deck and  proposal with pricing we discussed. Don’t be put off by the final cost in the proposal. 
😊
  To build the proposal I had to assume some things around the final number of sessions and the specific manager/leader training you might be interested in. Note that any of the products in the deck can be swapped out for assumptions made in the proposal.
 
Either way, think of this as a menu that we can customize accordingly.
 
You’ll notice that I did not provide pricing on the Diversity Leadership Governance piece yet. I need to talk with the team about how best to represent that outside of the ERG/BRG Consulting Package. As I was reviewing the program I noticed that there wasn’t a clean line item for that piece alone. I will work to get you that tomorrow.
 
Please let me know if you want to meet and discuss anything sent here. We can schedule a follow up call for end of this week/early next week at your convenience.
 
Best,
 
Chuck

Hello Rebecca, 
  
Here is my estimate according to what you provided and all the files, I have divided it by files: 
  
Understanding Your Cultural Lens_FINAL 
Linguistic QA: 7 hs 
Post DTP QA: 2 hs 
LATAM_LeadingInclusively-Solo_2024_FINALv2 
Linguistic QA: 12 hs 
Post DTP QA: 3 hs 
  
TOTAL QA TIME
: 24 hs / Language 
TOTAL USD:
 
1800 USD per language
. 
  
  
Linguistic QA: Implies editing translations 
Post DTP QA: involves making sure layout after translation and DTP mirrors exactly as source. 
Both tasks include the revision of everything translated and formatted by client, this includes subtitles of videos. Notes were not included in the estimate. 
These costs also include the implementation of edits in PPT but NOT in videos. If subtitles need to be modified, those costs will be analyzed separately. 
  
Please let me know if this is clear or if the estimate should be provided in any different way. 
  
  
Cecilia Mariotta

subject: An email was logged on records you're following
body:
An email was logged on records you're following
 
 
Hi. 
  
Some thoughts (If they are too late in the process we can save them for later): 
  
The second options in questions 1 and 2 are media/advertising/messaging related. While honing your message accurately IS a result of having diverse folks in the decision making process, I think we could mention the higher probability of developing new products and services that appeal to groups outside of a company’s traditional market. 
  
Question 3 needs an example statement. 
How about something like, “I don’t see why we need to spend extra money searching for 
new
 talent. We've been successful hiring a certain type of worker throughout our history.” 
  
The examples in Question 4 indirectly respond to the statement. 
A better response might be, “Hiring quotas have been illegal for some time. What some confuse with quotas are better described as earnest attempts to ensure that underrepresented workers, however that’s defined in your workplace, aren’t underrepresented because of harmful policies and practices.” 
  
Question 5 needs an example statement. 
Not sure that the response resonates as much as it could. Being ignored because of where you grew up seems safe. How might other people know where you grew up? Also, and this is just me, but the only thing divisive about the ‘identity politics’ is that it offends people who don’t have to consider their identity day to day. 
  
Question 6 needs an example statement. 
Something like, “Why is any of this important? We’re a company, not a social nonprofit.” 
  
Apologies if this is late in the game. If we are going to have the EXAMPLE rows present we need to fill them or remove them. There also isn’t an option statement that ties DEI work to company values, which is what I hear from the companies still committed to this work. For some companies this is still a values play. 
  
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
 
Chief Executive Officer 
LCW

Thank you very much, Chuck! I've had some time to go through the menu and have a few questions about pricing for each course. 
I'm interested in the following sessions, divided by type. Are they priced by the hour, by the session or both? Let's assume we have 40 people in each session, would we need 3 or 4 sessions of each? 
Facilitated learning
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion (all audiences)
Inclusion Skill-Building: Brave Conversations on Race + Power of AllyshipCulture (all audiences)
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion + Leading with Conscious Inclusion (managers & leaders) 
eLearning
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion (all audiences)
Fostering Collaboration (all audiences)
Mini-workshops
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion

Thank you!

From: Sufi, Amtul Sent: Wednesday, March 19, 2025 6:53:56 PM To: Andrea Wicks Bowles ; Grant, Cindy Cc: Chuck Adams Subject: RE: [External]LCW Resources Hi Andrea, Thank you for providing this.  In follow-up to our discussion, I have listed below the pre-work courses that we would like the team to take in advance of LCW content.  Again, this is live-facilitated content that is facilitated by the Office of DEI.  Based on your review, we would love to know what you are thinking would be good to supplement this content and what the timeline and associated costs may be.  Please let me know if you have any questions, and when would be a good for you to meet in follow-up to discuss further/plan. DEI annual required education, which is online “bite-sized” modules, that cover topics including (In total ~25 min of content): Inclusive Language and Belonging Identifying Microaggressions and Stereotypes Upstander Interventions Expanding your Network How to Intervene with Skill Facing Criticism Microaggressions & Allyship:  90-minute course in which you will learn about micro-aggressions in the workplace and three roles one can have in relation to them: actor, target, and observer. Through the lens of allyship, we will review real clinical examples and explore strategies to intervene and manage after a microaggression. Individual Connection to Bias and Privilege for Leaders:  120-minute course designed for people leaders including managers, supervisors, directors and above, understanding how each of us are impacted by bias and privilege are key components to the personal development we are all called to do if we want to deliver on our ICARE values equitably. Exploring these concepts and how they apply to our leadership skills is a critical first step to leading inclusively. Join this introduction to these concepts to begin your self-reflection journey in DEI as a leader and gain insights into building DEI into your team. Leveraging Privilege for Breakthroughs:  (this has not yet been confirmed to be part of the learning journey):  120-minute course that enables the learner to take a deeper dive into a self-reflective and action-oriented exploration of how we, as leaders, must push through discomfort to create meaningful change within our spheres of influence. Participants in this course will be challenged to identify the behaviors required to truly fulfill the concept of leveraging one’s privilege and ways to foster conversation with their teams. Thank you, Amtul Amtul Sufi (Pronounced Umthul Soofi), MBA Pronouns: She/Her/Hers Director Office of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Check out the new 2024 DEI Impact Report Ways to get involved! Nominate yourself or a colleague for a cultural/awareness/recognition month employee spotlight. Volunteer to be a storytime reader for a cultural/awareness month. Ways to get involved! Nominate yourself or a colleague for a cultural/awareness/recognition month employee spotlight. Volunteer to be a storytime reader for a cultural/awareness month. 
www.chop.edu
 CHOP’s Commitment to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion CHOP is committed to building an inclusive culture where employees feel a sense of belonging, connection, and community within their workplace. We are a team dedicated to fostering an environment that allows all to be their authentic selves. We are focused on attracting, cultivating, and retaining diverse talent who can help us deliver on our mission to be a world leader in the advancement of healthcare for children. We strongly encourage all candidates of diverse backgrounds and lived experiences to apply. From: Andrea Wicks Bowles Sent: Friday, March 7, 2025 2:27 PM To: Grant, Cindy ; Sufi, Amtul Cc: Chuck Adams Subject: [External]LCW Resources Hi Cindy and Amtul. It was a pleasure speaking with you yesterday.  Chuck and I look forward to our next conversations. Attached is a document that had been shared with Gilbert.  I wanted to draw your attention to the following: IDI Information and description of the process (3 slides). Building a Culture of Inclusion (for Managers and Leaders) (2 slides). Managing Bias for Managers and Leaders (2 slides). This information will give you a better understanding of what we discussed.  Of course, further clarity is needed, but I thought you might find this material interesting. Have a lovely weekend.
